Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: What had he done to make him fly the land?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Ross
Act4Scene2.text: You must have patience, madam.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: His flight was madness. When our actions do not, our fears do make us traitors.
Act4Scene2.translation: To run away was foolish. When our actions don't make us traitors, our fears do.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Ross
Act4Scene2.text: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Wisdom? To leave his wife, to leave his babes, His mansion and his titles in a place From whence himself does fly?

responses.text: All is the fear, and nothing is the love

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: All is the fear, and nothing is the love, As little is the wisdom, where the flight So runs against all reason.
Act4Scene2.translation: Macduff's leave was all fear and no love. It was not wise to run away from his wife, children, home, and titles.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Ross
Act4Scene2.text: My dearest coz, I pray you school yourself. But for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows the fits o’ th’ season.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Ross
Act4Scene2.text: I take my leave of you. Shall not be long but I’ll be here again. My pretty cousin, blessing upon you.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Sirrah, your father’s dead. And what will you do now? How will you live?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: As birds do, mother.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: What, with worms and flies?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: With what I get, I mean; and so do they. My father is not dead.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Yes, he is dead. How wilt thou do for a father?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Nay, how will you do for a husband?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Then you’ll buy ’em to sell again.

responses.text: Thou speak’st with all thy wit

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Thou speak’st with all thy wit, And yet, i’ faith, with wit enough for thee.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Was my father a traitor, mother?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Ay, that he was.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: What is a traitor?

responses.text: Why, one that swears and lies

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Why, one that swears and lies.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: And be all traitors that do so?

responses.text: Every one that does so is a traitor and must be hanged

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Every one that does so is a traitor and must be hanged.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Every one.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Who must hang them?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Why, the honest men.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enough to beat the honest men and hang up them.

responses.text: Now God help thee, poor monkey!

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Now God help thee, poor monkey! But how wilt thou do for a father?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: If he were dead, you’d weep for him. If you would not, it were a good sign that I should quickly have a new father.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Poor prattler, how thou talk’st!

Act4Scene2.speaker: Messenger
Act4Scene2.text: Bless you, fair dame. I doubt some danger does approach you nearly. If you will take a homely man’s advice, Be not found here.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Messenger
Act4Scene2.text: Hence with your little ones! Heaven preserve you! I dare abide no longer.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: Whither should I fly? I have done no harm.

responses.text: But I remember now I am in this earthly world

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: But I remember now I am in this earthly world, where to do harm is often laudable, to do good sometime accounted dangerous folly.
Act4Scene2.translation: But I remember that in this world, doing harm is often praised, while doing good is sometimes considered foolish and dangerous.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: What are these faces?

Act4Scene2.speaker: Murderer
Act4Scene2.text: Where is your husband?

responses.text: I hope in no place so unsanctified Where such as thou mayst find him

Act4Scene2.speaker: Lady Macduff
Act4Scene2.text: I hope in no place so unsanctified Where such as thou mayst find him.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Murderer
Act4Scene2.text: He’s a traitor.

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: Thou liest, thou shag-eared villain!

Act4Scene2.speaker: Murderer
Act4Scene2.text: What, you egg? Stabbing him. Young fry of treachery!
Act4Scene2.translation: What's that, you runt? Son of a traitor!

Act4Scene2.speaker: Son
Act4Scene2.text: He has killed me, mother. Run away, I pray you.
